Pree: A simple tool to easily build no-build websites.

Some context: I wanted to write some docs but didn't want to use a framework or an overly complicated toolchain. Web components + ESM + modern CSS seems to almost resolve any need for a framework or a toolchain for such a project, though a few issues remained, mainly the fact that web components render on client side (imagine a web component that renders markdown, this means clients should download a markdown parser and wait for the markdown of the page to be parsed before they can see the content).So I made a little tool, pree, whose main job is to pre-render web components (using declarative shadow DOM), so for making such static websites you could only use the web standards without sacrificing performance, UX or DX.

GIMP

Id use gimp - If you build websites, you should deffo spend some time to learn how to use any image processor. For your task, however, it doesn't seem necessary? Just put your image in a div and style the div to whatever portrait shape you need?

Paidaffinity software suit (adobe is better but I hate their pricing strategy)Freevector editing: Inkscape can convert your raster image in svg, fix perspective, etc. with results depending on the complexity of your logo. It has very powerful snapping features, vector effects, plugins, and the output is in actual svg format. Graphite (web app) is not as powerful as inkscape yet, but it should already be sufficient for your task (resizing a logo + separating layers), and you don't need to download anything. You could also use figma for simple vector manipulation, it's not a drawing software but it does the job.raster editing: photopea (free photoshop, web based. Not as complete as photoshop or gimp but sufficient for most tasks). For digital painting, use krita . If you need to fix the logo with some brush, krita brush engines are very very good.For your particular task, if you don't have the logo in svg, I would use photopea. Otherwise, use inkscape.If you need to remove a background, you can use one of the aforementioned tools, or go on a dedicated website like https://www.adobe.com/express/feature/image/remove-backgroundRemember to optimise your assets, if it's svg use svgomg (integrated into inkscape or as a standalone) or a website like https://vecta.io/nano, otherwise use https://squoosh.app/If your logo is in vector format, you can crop it with https://svgcrop.com/ to remove the blank spaces.If you want to see more alternatives :https://alternativeto.net/software/adobe-photoshop/?license=freehttps://alternativeto.net/software/adobe-illustrator/?license=free
Photoshop

For simple image editing tasks like adding a white rectangle to convert a landscape logo to portrait or separating foreground and background, you can use simpler software like Paint.NET, Adobe Photoshop Express, or even online tools like Canva or Pixlr. These tools are easier to use and don't require as much expertise as GIMP.https://jagmohankrishan.com/

Photoshop if you have it, photopea.com if you don't.¬† Both are powerful pieces of software so you might have to look stuff up like you mentioned.¬† Gaining some some minor image editing skills can be pretty useful in web dev... you don't wanna be blocked when you just need some small tweaks. whats up with the recent news about apple killing web apps in the eu, can u explain to me like im 5:Sure, I'll try to explain it to you like you're 5. Web apps are like websites that you can add to your home screen and use like regular apps. They can do things like send you notifications and work offline. Some people like web apps because they are faster, cheaper, and easier to make than regular apps.Apple is a big company that makes iPhones and iPads. They have their own rules for how apps should work on their devices. They also have their own store where you can buy or download apps. Apple likes to keep their store and their devices safe and secure, so they check every app before they let it in their store. They also charge money to the app makers for using their store and their devices.The EU is a group of countries in Europe that work together and make some rules for everyone. They want to make sure that people have more choices and fair prices when they use technology. They don't like it when big companies like Apple have too much power and control over what people can do with their devices. They made a new rule called the DMA that says Apple has to let other people make web apps and use different browsers on their devices.Apple says that they can't follow the new rule because it would make their devices less safe and secure. They say that web apps need to use a special thing called WebKit that makes them work well with Safari, their own browser. They say that if they let other browsers use their own things instead of WebKit, then some bad web apps could get into your device and do bad things to it. They also say that making web apps work with other browsers would be very hard and take a lot of time.So, Apple decided to stop letting people add web apps to their home screen in the EU. They say that this is the only way they can follow the new rule and keep their devices safe and secure. They say that web apps are not very popular anyway, and that people can still use them in Safari or other browsers. But some people are not happy with Apple's decision. They say that Apple is just trying to keep their power and money, and that they are making web apps worse for everyone. They also say that web apps are very useful and important, and that Apple should find a better way to follow the new rule and support them.

Don't make up your own HTTP status codes.As for how to use the existing ones there are a couple of different schools of thought.You could try to embrace the HTTP status codes at your application level and use the one which best describes what's happening.Or you could leave those status codes at the HTTP level, and give your own signposting at your application level, which might be a status field of your response. When doing things this way you will treat any request which was handled as expected by your system, even if you handled an error situation, as an HTTP 200.One advantage to the latter is that the consumer of your API can more easily tell which responses they should try to parse and which they should not. If they get a 200, they know that it's going to be in the format that they expect from your application, and where to look for a possible structured error report. If they get some other HTTP status code they know that it's an exception.If the API tries to give different status codes depending on what happened, consuming the API becomes a little more difficult. It could be for example that a 4xx was generated either by the application or by some other layer, like a proxy, and confidence in how to handle the response disappears.You can tell I prefer the latter approach these days (I used to prefer the former), but I'm sure others feel otherwise and have good reasons.

First of all, React is a JavaScript framework that uses a virtual version of the DOM. The reason you would build the HTML outside of the HTML-files (like we used to back in the day) is mostly due to that virtual DOM, which enables reactivity and splitting up the code into re-usable components,It's far more complex than that, but that's the quick version.You can use React in different way, like "mounting" a react app / component or simply building the whole website as a React app.Your questions cover many long topics, and to answer your SEO question; yes it has implications, but you have different ways of "rendering" the React code these days:SSR (Server-Side Rendered): Renders the React code to HTML server-side, much like PHP.SSG (Server-Side Generated): Pre-renders the React code to HTML server-side, often referred as static.Client-side only: Only render the React code in the client, I guess it's the SPA (Single-Page App) approach.I'd say the first ones are most common these days, using frameworks like Next.js for React.

There are some advanced setups that can allow you to use React in piecemeal in a static HTML/CSS, but for where you're at you should avoid those to start. This is not a common use case.For all intents and purposes, React should be considered your full framework that handles all your page and component creation. JSX, React's preferred syntax, involves colocating and writing your JavaScript and HTML together in the file. Thats the way web frameworks have moved to in the modern web, there's usually some version of a virtual DOM and your framework of choice handles all the rendering of markup instead of just adding specific reactivity to a button by querying the ID or something.If the React experience with JSX templating is not your cup of tea, you want a framework where there are more distinct separations for markup, styles, and logic, I'd suggest looking at Angular or Vue as they both approach component/page creation with some more clear separations. You could also just use plain old JavaScript or Jquery inside script tags, still totally valid!As far as that tutorial goes, the index.js stuff is fine--like I mentioned React components and pages are full on JavaScript files that render out to HTML in the broswer. However, if it's not clicking with you then there's plenty others out there. I've been a huge fan of Wes Bos as an instructor, and he has an up to date React for a Beginners course that is on sale. If you want something free I'd honestly start with the [react.dev official docs](react.dev) or try this started project from Web Dev Simplified where he runs through a tutorial in the official React docs.If you're worried about SEO, React docs officially recommends using Next.JS . It's a "meta frameworks" that bootstraps and extends a React project with routing, file directories, and most importantly an easy way to server render your website like a static HTML or PHP website. There are some more things that NextJS can handle on top of that, but you can explore those in the docs as need be. You're already learning a ton and don't need to overwhelm yourself more than intended!And lastly, on that note, feel free to narrow your scope a bit too if it helps. Just focus on a few basic tutorials, make the standard Todo list app, then add in tailwind and page structure and all that fun stuff, haha.I know this was a huge info dump, hope it helps, and feel free to ask more questions if you have em!
